**Do the rats of New York City crave the unctuous, cheesy, saucy, crusty delight that draws tourists from around the world to the Big Apple—the unrivaled, saliva-inducing culinary masterpiece that is pizza?**

![](https://i.cbc.ca/1.3237852.1442878202!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_1180/pizza-rat.jpg?im=Resize%3D860)

While many New Yorkers (our renowned Rat Czar included) view their rodent neighbors as adversaries, we may have more in common than the skeptics care to admit.

Rats have long been spotted hauling slices many times their size through the streets and subway tunnels—a dedication that rivals even the most determined late-night pizza seeker. Our team at the Pizza Rat Research Institute at Columbia Mailman is here to investigate the truth: *do rats actually like pizza?*

Join us as we embark on this exploratory analysis to finally shed light on a question that has captivated—and perhaps haunted—our city for far too long.
